title: What is the Great Work of Alchemy and how does it differ from popular belief?
first_phrase: In this final part of the text, the author delves into the imperfections of common understanding and observations of magic and alchemy. The first two degrees of the Great Work, the "Projection upon Mercury" and "Transmutation into Pure Silver," lead to the final degree, the "Projection of the Sun." The author warns against oversimplifications of these concepts and emphasizes the importance of conquering the Arcanum to gain a true understanding of creative activity. The story of Princess Belika and the warning about dividing into two upon eating the fruit is a symbol reiterated in the Genesis story and the anguilla, representing the permanent vitality in broken parts. The text concludes by discussing the careful and patient work necessary to digest the Mercurio, a cosmic animal matter, in the creation of the Great Work.

Dopo infinite peripezie approda ad un'isola dove un albero aveva la frutta di una bellezza abbagliante. Appena la principessa stende la mano per cogliere un frutto, una voce, dal tronco, la ammonisce: Non mangiarne: Chi ne mangia sarà' diviso in due. Immagine stessa riportata dal Serpente della Genesi, il serpente che e' simbolo della vitalità' permanente nelle sue parti quando le parti sono tronche. last_phrase: In conclusion, the story of the princess Belika and her journey to the Island of the Seven Moors to retrieve the Solomon's ring reveals a deeper meaning about the alchemical process and the importance of patience and focus in achieving one's goals. The symbolism in this story and in the Clavis of Hercules can also be seen in the pastoral staff of Catholic bishops, which should represent their mastery of the philosopher's stone. These insights can provide valuable guidance for those seeking to understand the mysteries of alchemy and spiritual development.
